docs.lead_paragraph: The world's third set of septuplets five boys and two girls, each so tiny they could fit in the palm of a man's hand- -- were born at Georgetown University Hospital late Thursday, delivered by a team of doctors and nurses who had spent weeks running through practice drills. The babies, weighing 2 to 2.4 pounds, were in critical condition today. Their mother, whose name is being withheld, was said by hospital officials to be comfortable and serene.

headline.main: Septuplets Born in Capital Are Third Set in the World

docs.abstract: Woman gives birth to septuplets in Georgetown Hospital in Washington, DC; babies, five boys and two girls, weigh 2 to 2.4 pounds; were conceived using fertility drugs (M)
docs.snippet: The  world's third set of septuplets  five boys and two girls, each so tiny they could fit in the palm of a man's hand- -- were born at Georgetown University Hospital late Thursday, delivered by a team of doctors and nurses who had spent weeks...

docs.lead_paragraph: American women passed syphilis to their babies last year at less than half the rate they did just four years ago, bringing health officials closer to stamping out the disease, the government said today. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recorded 529 cases of congenital syphilis last year, down from 1,077 in 1997. That puts the current rate at about 1 infected baby for every 7,500 live births.
docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says that it recorded 529 cases of congenital syphilis last year, down from 1,077 in 1997 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Down to Earth Another remake of ''Here Comes Mr. Jordan'' (1941) by way of ''Heaven Can Wait'' (1978) introduces Lance Barton (Chris Rock, left), a really bad comedian who dreams of appearing at the Apollo in Harlem. Instead he is hit by a truck, sent to heaven 44 years early by mistake, then put back as a white 53-year-old magnate named Wellington, who has just been murdered by his wife. The old Wellington has been a brute, closing hospitals and the like, but the new Wellington suddenly has heart to go along with Lance's comedic ambitions. As for Mr. Rock's intentions, Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times, fans ''are going to want a movie with the same acidulous funkiness that he brings to his stand-up, and they won't find that.''
docs.abstract: Brief reviews of films now released on video: Down to Earth, Monkeybone, Malena and Snatch; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In an unusual action against a ''deadbeat dad,'' the Wisconsin Supreme Court has upheld a probation order that bars a man convicted of failure to pay child support from having more children unless he shows that he can support all his offspring. The 34-year-old man, David Oakley, who has nine children by four women and owes $25,000 in support, faces eight years in prison if he violates the condition.

headline.main: Father Owing Child Support Loses a Right To Procreate

docs.abstract: Wisconsin Supreme Court upholds probation order that bars man convicted of failure to pay child support from having more children unless he shows he can support all of his offspring; man, David Oakley, has nine children by four women and owes $25,000 in support; he faces eight years in prison if he violates condition; case splits court, 4 to 3, with all four male justices joining in ruling and three female justices opposed to it as unconstitutional intrusion on basic right to procreate; Julie Sternberg of American Civil Liberties Union says ruling creates dangerous precedent (M)

docs.abstract: Dr Leonard Wolf letter, commenting on July 5 article on risks if natural birth following Caesarean, says women should not be discouraged from considering vaginal birth after previous Caesarean section since Caesarean has almost as many complications
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''A Risk Is Found in Natural Birth After Caesarean'' (front page, July 5):

docs.lead_paragraph: When the United States' first test tube baby was born in 1981, the Jones Institute for Reproductive Medicine, where she was conceived, found itself at the center of an intense debate over whether scientists should tamper with the beginnings of human life. Now, by dipping into the tumultuous waters of human embryonic stem cell research, the Jones Institute, a fertility clinic in Norfolk, Va., is reliving those times.

headline.main: For Clinic, Stem Cell Test Is Rebirth Of Old Debate

docs.abstract: Dr Howard W Jones Jr, 90-year-old co-founder of Jones Institute for Reproductive Medicine in Norfolk, Va, stands behind work of institute's scientists, who recently announced they had mixed eggs and sperm for express purpose of extracting stem cells from resulting embryos; research has drawn opposition from religious conservatives, as well as Roman Catholic Church, because it results in destruction of embryos, microscopic clusters of cells that some regard as nascent human life; Jones Institute experiment has startled even some proponents of stem cell science, because it breaks medical taboo against mixing eggs and sperm to create fresh embryos expressly for research; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study of the health of Newark's children has found favorable trends in teenage pregnancy, child abuse and juvenile arrests but disturbing ones in sexually transmitted diseases, infant mortality and asthma. The study, ''Kids Count,'' by the Association for Children of New Jersey, says reports of venereal diseases rose 31.4 percent in 1999, the most recent year for which data are available, or more than double the 13 percent statewide increase, while infant mortality was 13.5 deaths per 1,000 births in 1999, and 6.4 statewide. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Mixed Report On Children's Health

docs.abstract: Association for Children of New Jersey study of health of Newark's children finds favorable trends in some health areas and disturbing ones in others (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Terry Coffey was 27 weeks pregnant when she was admitted to the hospital for observation because her blood pressure had shot up and her obstetrician worried that her life might be in danger. The diagnosis was preeclampsia, a disorder that is characterized mainly by the sudden onset of high blood pressure during pregnancy. Mrs. Coffey, a nurse who lives in Westchester County, thought her doctor was overreacting. Although she knew that preeclampsia could be dangerous, she felt fine.

headline.main: Dangerous Complication of Pregnancy Becomes More Common

docs.abstract: Preeclampsia, dangerous pregnancy disorder characterized mainly by sudden onset of high blood pressure, seems to be on rise, with case reports rising by 40 percent in United States over past decade; some experts see rise linked to increasing number of women delaying pregnancy until late 30's and early 40's and to increased use of assisted-reproduction techniques that often result in multiple births; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A July 2 editorial says nurses have been easily trained to administer voluntary H.I.V. tests so women and their newborns can take simple, cheap drugs to prevent transmission. Unfortunately, volunteerism has failed globally in the war against AIDS, which will be won only when routine testing becomes the norm.
docs.abstract: Dr Sanford F Kuvin letter says global war against AIDS will be won only through prenatal testing, confidential reporting to health authorities and mandatory partner notification (S)
